summary: This is an internal email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff discussing the autopsy report of Jeffrey Epstein. It details the office's coordination with the NYC Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) to redact sensitive investigative materials from the report before its release to Epstein's brother, Mark Epstein. The email also mentions a handwritten note found in Epstein's cell.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.role: Next of kin of Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Identified as Jeffrey Epstein's brother and the next of kin who has requested the autopsy report from OCME.

persons.name: Lt.
persons.role: MCC guard and potential key witness
persons.context: A lieutenant who was on duty at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) at the time Jeffrey Epstein's body was found. The FBI interviewed him, and a draft 302 of that interview was provided to OCME.

connections.description: Mark Epstein is identified as the brother and next of kin of the deceased Jeffrey Epstein.
The lieutenant was a guard on duty at the MCC when Jeffrey Epstein's body was discovered, making him a key witness to the circumstances.

events.title: Planned submission of redactions to OCME
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office plans to provide their proposed redactions for the Epstein autopsy report to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The OCME autopsy concluded the cause was suicide.

locations: Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME), New York City
keyFacts: The NYC Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) completed a full autopsy report on Jeffrey Epstein, concluding his death was a suicide.
The U.S. Attorney's Office provided sensitive investigative materials to OCME for the autopsy, including a draft FBI 302 of an interview with a key MCC guard witness (Lt.).

The U.S. Attorney's Office requested OCME redact sensitive materials (like guard names, witness statements, and MCC documents) from the autopsy report before releasing it to Epstein's brother, Mark Epstein, to protect the ongoing investigation.
A handwritten note was found in Epstein's cell at the time of his death. Authorities assessed it as a list of grievances about prison conditions, not a suicide note.
The OCME follows a policy of releasing autopsy reports to next of kin in suicide cases but typically withholds them in homicide cases out of respect for ongoing investigations.
